source.raw_text:
Weighted push-ups are a compound movement primarily targeting the chest (pectoralis major), shoulders (anterior deltoids), and triceps, while also heavily engaging core stabilizers (abs, obliques, erector spinae), serratus anterior, glutes, and back muscles for stability and full-body tension, using a pushing motion (concentric) and lowering (eccentric) to build upper body pushing strength. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]  
Muscles Worked 

• Primary Movers (Pushing): 

    • Pectoralis Major (Chest): Main muscle for pushing the body up. 
    • Triceps Brachii (Back of Arms): Extends the elbow to push up. 
    • Anterior Deltoids (Front Shoulders): Assist in lifting the arm forward and stabilizing the shoulder. 

• Stabilizers & Secondary Muscles (Throughout the movement): 

    • Serratus Anterior: Moves and stabilizes the shoulder blade (scapula). 
    • Core (Rectus Abdominis, Obliques, Transverse Abdominis): Keeps the torso rigid and prevents sagging. 
    • Glutes & Lower Back (Erector Spinae): Maintain a straight line and prevent hip sagging. 
    • Latissimus Dorsi & Trapezius (Back): Help with shoulder stability. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7]  

Movement Pattern (Concentric & Eccentric) 

1. Starting Position (Plank): Body in a straight line from head to heels, hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart, core braced, glutes tight, weight distributed evenly. 
2. Eccentric Phase (Lowering): Slowly bend elbows, lowering your chest towards the floor, keeping your body straight and shoulder blades stable. 
3. Concentric Phase (Pushing): Press powerfully through your hands to extend your elbows, returning to the starting plank position, focusing on driving through the chest, shoulders, and triceps. 
4. Key Technique: Maintain a tight core and glutes throughout to prevent your lower back from arching or hips from dropping, ensuring the movement is a full-body effort. [1, 3, 4, 8, 9]  

**Citations:**

[1] https://dieringe.com/exercises/weighted-push-ups
[2] https://www.masterclass.com/articles/weighted-push-ups-guide

[5] https://www.nike.com/il/a/what-muscles-do-push-ups-work-out
[6] https://www.onepeloton.com/blog/what-muscles-do-push-ups-work
[7] https://www.fitbarstrong.com/blog/muscles-worked-doing-pushups
[8] https://www.endomondo.com/exercise/weighted-push-up
[9] https://www.physio-pedia.com/Pushups
